loans.name: Ajibola

texts.en: Ajibola R. hails from Okoko Lagos State Nigeria; she sells frozen food, drinks and popcorn. She is 32 years old, with one child and has enough time and energy to handle this business properly. She requests the sum of $700 to enable her to buy more frozen food and drinks for sale. She has been operating this business since 1997.

loans.use: To buy more frozen food and drinks for sale.

loans.name: Ana Mercy

texts.es:
Mrs. Ana Mercy R. V. is a member of the Communal Bank “VISION 2000.” She lives in San Martín region of Picota province in San Hilarión state. Her business is located on Marginal avenue at Fernando Belaude Terri highway, where she sells groceries, candy, and other edible products for daily consumption.

Previously she sold clothing for children, men and women, but she didn’t have a great demand for her products. So she decided to open a grocery store, with the goal of improving her income and contributing to the improvement of her community.

With a loan for S/3000.00, which will be repaid in 6 monhts, she will buy a variety of packaged candy, sacks of rice and sugar, personal care items, items for the home, school and office supplies and stock up on soda pop.

Ana Mercy has 3 children together with her husband who support her always in her business. Together they dream of having a bigger business and ensure the well-being of their family.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Ana Mercy R. V., es socia del Banco Comunal “VISION 2000” vive en la Región San Martín y Provincia de Picota y distrito de San Hilarión, su negocio está ubicado en la Av. Marginal , carretera Fernando Belaude Terri , en el vende abarrotes en general, golosinas y otros productos comestibles de consumo diario.

Anteriormente vendía ropas de niños, caballeros y damas, que no tuvo la demanda necesaria, por lo que decidió implementar una bodega, con visión a mejorar su economía y contribuir al progreso de la comunidad.

Con el préstamo de S/. 3000.00, el cual será pagado en 6 cuotas, comprará golosinas en paquetes de distintas variedades, arroz y azúcar en sacos, útiles de aseo personal y para el hogar, útiles escolares y de oficina, además de surtir con bebidas gasificadas.

Ana Mercy tiene 03 hijos que junto a su esposo son quienes la apoyan siempre en el negocio, juntos sueñan con tener un negocio más grande y asegurar el bienestar de su familia.

loans.use: With the loan she will buy more products for her store

loans.name: Fatuma Namagembe's Group

texts.en:
Fatuma is the leader of a five-member group. She is 28 years old and married, with five children. They range in age from 6 to 17. All of them are still in school. The community she lives and works in is semi-urban.

She has been selling charcoal and water and operating a salon for the last seven years. She purchases charcoal from roving vendors in vehicles. She has a semi-permanent wooden structure by the roadside in Kawaala, a very busy trading center just outside Kampala, where she displays the sacks and sells full sacks and small amounts. The salon is also nearby. She sells tap water but has a big tank in which she catches rain water for sale. There is a market for what she does.

Her main challenges include high transport costs, which are embedded in the high wholesale prices, thieves, and flooding that limits clients' movements. The charcoal also gets wet when it rains.

She also has been able to construct three rental rooms, which greatly contribute to the family welfare.

She plans to open a retail shop, construct more rooms for renting out and acquire another water tank. Fatuma has successfully paid back more than ten loans.

loans.use: To increase her stock of products

loans.name: Lucía

texts.es:
Lucía is a mother of two small children, who are her motivation to work hard and make headway with her and her husband's motorcycle transportation business. She handles the vehicle with a lot of care and detail so she can have better earnings, and above all makes sure that it's always well maintained to prevent future problems.

Lucía has saved some money to acquire a new motorcycle and thus increase the daily income for her family. But what she has saved so far is not enough to buy one, and she and her husband are hoping you will help them with this purchase.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

Lucía es una madre de familia de dos pequeños hijos quienes son su motor de trabajo y por quienes trata de salir adelante junto a su esposo con quien trabaja en su motocarro. Ella administra el vehículo con mucho cuidado y detalle para que pueda tener mayores ingresos, y vela que su movilidad y herramienta de trabajo sea bien cuidada, sobre todo tenga los respectivos mantenimientos para prevenir problemas futuros. Lucía tiene ahorrado algo de dinero para poder adquirir un nuevo motocarro, y así ampliar los ingresos diarios de su familia. Pero lo que hasta ahora tiene, no alcanza para la compra de su nuevo motocarro, esta pareja de esposos recurre a ustedes esperanzados en que puedan ayudarlos a comprar su nuevo motocarro.

loans.use: Enlarge her transportation reach with the purchase of a new motorcycle / Ampliar su campo de trasporte con la compra de un nuevo motocarro.

loans.name: Alba Sobeyda

texts.es:
Hello, how are you?  My name is Alba R. and I work selling a variety of products that are commonly consumed every day.  I am 36 years old.  My business is my only source of income for sustaining my home.  Unfortunately, I have difficulties with my daughter because she has an illness that has incapacitated her for life and she is paralyzed.  So, because of this illness I spend a lot of money each month.  Thank God I have the help of my husband to get ahead, but I need to grow my business.  At this time we are selling lottery tickets and that has helped us a lot because the tickets sell a great deal in our country.  For this reason I need monetary assistance to get ahead with my business, my home and my family.Translated from Spanish by Hugh Yarbrough, Kiva Volunteer.


hola como estan, mi nombre es Alba R. me dedico a la venta de varios productos que son de consumo diario, tengo 36 años de edad, mi negocio es mi unica fuente de ingresos para el sustento de mi hogar,  lastimosamente tengo problemas con mi hija ya que ella tiene una enfermedad que la tiene incapacitada de por vida, tiene paralisis, entonces con esta enfermedad gasto mucho dinero mensualmente, gracias a Dios tengo la ayuda de mi esposo para salir adelante, pero necesito hacer crecer mas mi negocio, en estos momentos estamos vendiendo loteria lo cual nos ha ayudado mucho ya que la loto se vende bastante en nuestro pais.
por tal razon necesito ayuda monetaria para salir adelante con mi negocio mi hogar y mi familia.

loans.use: Purchase basic grains (rice, beans, corn, etc.), sugar, coffee, toilet paper, churros, soft drinks, lard, juices, salt, eggs, cereals, crackers, candy, batteries, bread, etc.

loans.name: Lluvia De Oro Group

texts.es:
The Lluvia D. Oro (“Gold Rain”) group is maD. up of thirteen members. The group was founded in 2007 by Sra. Noemi H., who also gave the group the name Lluvia D. Oro. Of the 13 group members, eight of them are original members from the first loan cycle, and the remaining five members joined in the second cycle.

The group is involved in various businesses: Rodrigo, Alejandra and Martha sell clothing, Damaso sells livestock, Silveria sells cosmetics, Arely works as household help, Florencia, Maria Elena, and Karen sell food (salchipapas (French fries with hot dog slices), sweets, dry goods and meat), and the other Silveria knits sweaters. Most of the group members plan to use their Kiva loans to buy more merchandise or supplies for their respective businesses.

All of the group members are committed to repaying this loan on time, so that they can continue to work with AgroCapital in the future.

Translated and elaborated by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva fellow

CONFORMADO POR 13 PERSONAS QUE SE ESTABLECIERON DESD. EL PRIMER CICLO, EL GRUPO LLUVIA D. ORO EMPIEZA EN EL AÑO 2007 DOND. LA SRA NOEMI H. CONFORMO EL GRUPO Y DONDOLE EL NOMBRE D. LLUVIA D. ORO.

LAS TRECE PERSONAS QUE CONFORMAN EL GRUPO, SON YA 8 PERSONAS QUE SE MANTIENEN DESD. EL PRIMER CICLO Y LAS DEMAS RETORNAN DEL SEGUNDO CICLO.

TODAS COMPROMETIENDOSE A LA CANCELACION D. SU DEUDA, PARA PODER SEGUIR TRABAJANDO CON LA INSTITUCION.
texts.en:
...

Translated from Spanish by Christian Jimenez, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy more merchandise/supplies for various businesses

loans.name: Azucena De Jesus

texts.es: Azucena R. P. es una señora de 40 años de edad, es casada, tien cuatro hijos con edades comprendidas de 17 años es un hijo que nacio con capacidades diferentes, otra hija de 15 años cursa el segundo año de secundaria, su otro hijo tiene 13 años estudia el quinto grado de primaria y su ultimo hijo tiene 7 años de edad y cursa el primer grado de primaria; su esposo es agricultor, sus aspiraciones en la vida es poder ayudar a sus hijos a ser profesionales del mañana, en medio de sus limitantes economicas, la actividad economica de la señora es una pulperia en su casa de habitacion la cual esta ubicada en el Kilometro 85 carretra leon managua, donde sus condiciones de vida son bastantes pobres pero tiene la fe en poder ir mejorando su casa poco a poco con las ganancias que le genere su pulperia ademas del credito, ademas de este pequeño negocio, tambine comercializa con frutas y verduras en el mercado la terminal de  buses en leon, como producto de lo que cosecha su esposo, actividad que realiza por la mañana quedando su esposo al frente de la pulperia, con el credito pretende ir creciendo en inventario de esta manera satisafcer su demanda por consiguiente diversificar sus productos.
texts.en:
Azucena R. P. is a 40 year old woman, married, with four children: a 17 year old son with special needs, a 15 year old daughter in her second year of secondary school, a 13 year old son studying 5th grade of primary school, and a 7 year old son in first grade of primary school. Her husband is a farmer. Her aspirations in life are to be able to help her children become professionals in the future. In light of their limited economic means, Azucena opened a small convenience store in their home which is located at kilometer 85 on the Leon-Managua highway, where the living conditions are rather poor but she has faith in being able to improve their home little by little with the earnings their store is generating. In addition to the loan, and this small business, she also sells fruits and vegetables in the Leon bus terminal market, as these are products her husband grows. She does this in the morning leaving her husband in the store. With the loan she will increase her inventory and in this way meet the demand to diversify her products.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy products to sell in their store

loans.name: Khan

texts.en:
Mrs. Khan L. is a villager in Roka Knouch Tboung village in Kampong Cham Province. She is 53 years old and the mother of four children.  One is employed in a garment factory, another is a construction worker, and the other two children are general workers. 

She and her husband, Mr. Shum Horn, are farmers. On their plantation they cannot cultivate rice because they do not have enough money to be productive, even though Mrs. Khan L.’s family members are involved in different businesses. Therefore Mrs. Khan L. decided to ask for a loan in order to get ahead. She would use the money to buy fertilizers and hire laborers to work in their field to make her crop more productive. Her husband is on the right of photo.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and hire laborers to work in their field to make her crop more productive.

loans.name: Elisabeth

texts.en:
Elisabeth T. was born on January 4, 1956 in Cotonou. She married Raymond Vodounon, a commercial agent, and lives in Cadjehoun. She has two daughters and a son, all in school, and she makes dresses and distributes wood and fuel to supplement her household income. Her first loan increased business, and now she requests another loan in order to diversify her business.

Translated from French:

Née le 04/01/1956 à Cotonou, elle est mariée à Vodounon Raymond agent commercial. Mère de 03 enfants dont 02 filles et un garçon tous scolarisés, elle est couturière et intervient aussi dans la distribution des noix d’acajou par saison depuis 02 ans et réside à Cadjehoun depuis 20 ans. Avec le premier crédit où elle a vu son activité accroître, elle sollicite un crédit de 180000 pour satisfaire à la demande de plus en plus croissante de sa clientèle.

loans.use: To purchase 14 bags of charcoal.

loans.name: Salorn

texts.en: Mrs. Salorn K. is a 30-year-old and she now lives in Siem Bouy village in Kampong Cham province. She is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice. Her husband, Mr. Leng Voeng, is a fisherman. He now wants to improve his family’s living conditions; thus, Mrs. Salorn K. decided to request a loan to buy fish and fish food for breeding. She has five children, four of whom are enrolled in the local school while the youngest one is too young to work or study because that child is one month old. Her husband is also in the picture with her.

loans.use: to buy fish and fish food for raising fish

loans.name: Women In Unity Group

texts.en:
These people are Fudia K., Fatmata M., Sarian M. and Aminata S.. They have called their group Women In Unity. They have re-paid previous loans successfully. They each received Le 1,000,000 in their previous loan. That loan helped them a lot. They were able to make a lot of profit from the loan, thus able to solve many of their problems. Today, they are requesting a new loan for the same amount of Le 1,000,000 each, to add to their businesses.

Fudia (second from right) is the leader of this group. Fudia was born in Masongbo village, on the outskirts of Makeni, in northern Sierra Leone. She is fifty years of age, married with six children – all of whom are now grown-ups. Her husband is a businessman, too. Fudia sells firewood as her main business but also sells underwear and clothes for children. She has been in this business for over 20 years now. With this loan of Le 1,000,000, Fudia will buy a truck load of firewood which costs Le 400,000 and the remaining Le 600,000 she will invest in her other business.

So far, Fudia faces no major challenge worth noting in her business. With this loan and the profit it will generate for her, Fudia’s life will be a happy one.

loans.use: Buy a truck load of firewood and goods for her other business

loans.name: Eva J.

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! This is 28-year-old Eva L. from Mbeya. She is married and has an 8-year-old child. Additionally, she is responsible for supporting two other dependants because they are orphans—their parents died of HIV. 

Eva has been running a salon since 2005. Hair, hair, and more hair! This is the place where you can buy long hair, short hair, curly hair, straight hair, red hair, or blue hair, and then have it attached to your head, woven, cut, or plaited, and made to look like your own.

She works at the business for 9-12 hours a day, 7 days a week. Eva currently earns about $100 USD a month from her business. She is requesting a loan of $450 USD to purchase more hair products and cosmetics. In the future, she plans to increase the quantity and the range of her business. Eva thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA: SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets. Women are considered non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This situation leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that it allows clients to use their equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase hair products and cosmetics

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
One of the members of Bamboo Center, under the Paglaum Development Program for Landless People, a microfinance program of Paglaum MPC, is Mrs. Teresita P..  She's been in Paglaum for four years and has enjoyed 6 loan cycles already. Currently, her loan will be used to purchase additional "banyeras" of fish.  Banyera is a kind of basin that is estimated to be 3 times larger than a regular basin, that is made of thick tin.  She sells her fish in the market, and some are taken to other places.  She has many customers already in town and even other places.

She is confident that her fish selling business will grow and develop to enable her to uplift their way of life. She said that hard work and thriftiness are a few of the keys to be successful. 

Teresita and her husband can't wait to see their children finish their studies and establish their chosen careers.

loans.use: To purchase additional bulk of fish to sell.

loans.name: Justo

texts.es:
El Sr. Justo C. tiene 7 años con su negocio venta de tacos, entre él y su esposa la señora Antonia Zarate son los que atiende el negocio.
Están solicitando un préstamo para poder reparar una camioneta y acondicionarla para vender tacos en diferentes partes de la ciudad de Nuevo Laredo. 
Planean pagar este crédito con las ganancias de su nuevo puesto de tacos ya que su esposa se encargara de atenderlo y el estará atendiendo el otro puesto. La persona que aparece en la foto es la señora Antonia ya que don Justo se encontraba surtiendo la mercancía para la venta de los tacos.
texts.en:
Mr. Justo C. has had his taco selling business for 7 years. He runs the business with his wife, Mrs. Antonia Zarate. They are asking for a loan to be able to fix and air condition a truck. They want to sell tacos in different parts of Nuevo Laredo (city). They plan to pay for the loan with the earnings from their new taco stand, which his wife will run. He will be seeing to the other stand. The person in the photo is Antonia. Justo was stocking up on goods for taco sales.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Vehicle repairs for taco sales

loans.name: Parvana

texts.en:
"Hi, dear lenders. Thank you very much for the loan. As you know, I applied for the loan from you two years ago. I improved my business with your help and support. I am very happy that Kiva raised the loan amount to $3000."

Parvana is applying for the second loan from Kiva. She applied for the first loan in 2007. She repaid this loan successfully.

This young woman would like to improve her cattle-breeding business. Now she needs a loan of 2000 AZN to buy five calves.

loans.use: To buy 5 calves

loans.name: Rina

texts.es:
Rina es socia del Banco Comunal Solución.
Rina es conviviente, tiene 35 años y 3 hijos, Rina tiene una bodega en su casa en donde vende abarrotes en general, verduras, frutas. Además Rina tiene cabinas de Internet actividad que realiza con la ayuda de su hijo, también vende útiles de escritorio.
Rina necesita un préstamo de 3000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de arroz, azúcar, fideo, leche.
Rina sueña con construir su casa, mejorar su casa y aumentar su negocio.
texts.en:
Rina is a member of the Solution Communal Bank. She lives with her partner, is 35 years old, and has three children. Rina has a small grocery store in her home where she sells general groceries, vegetables, and fruits. In addition, Rina has an internet café, which she runs with the help of her son. She also sells school supplies. Rina needs a loan of 3,000 soles, which she will invest in the purchase of rice, sugar, noodles and milk. Rina dreams of building a house, improving her home, and expanding her business.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Westin, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy rice, sugar, noodles and milk

loans.name: Lê Thị

texts.en:
H. Lê Thị makes a living primarily from raising cattle for sale. She is a 21-year-old woman living in the town of Quảng Xuong. She is married and has one school-aged child. H. has just started this business and earns approximately 600,000 VND a month.

In 2007, H. joined TYM Fund to gain access to financial services to help improve her situation and enable her to engage in business activities. H. has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000,000 VND from TYM Fund. This previous loan was used to purchase livestock to raise and sell. H. is now requesting a loan of 7,000,000 VND which will be used to purchase breeding livestock. This will be her third loan from TYM Fund. H. plans to use the additional revenue to expand her business.

No. 1433071555.

loans.use: To purchase livestock

loans.name: Daniela

texts.es:
La señora Daniela, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Virgen del Rosario”  que esta ubicado en la Comunidad D. Queñuani, distrito D. Yunguyo, Provincia D. Chuchito, Departamento D. Puno, ella tiene 52 años D. edad y es madre D. 06 hijos (3 D. ellos ya están casados), la sra. Daniela es casada, y tiene estudios D. Primaria completa, y vive en el Barrio Progreso D. Queñuani.

Trabaja con el movimiento Manuela Ramos desD. la fundación del Banco Comunal,  con un préstamo inicial D. S/. 300.00 nuevos soles  Daniela pudo iniciar su negocio D. compra y venta D. ají.  

En este momento ella requiere un préstamo D. S/. 3000.00 Nuevos soles, para poder invertir en su actual negocio, que es la compra y venta D. ají. El mismo que es vendido en las ferias D.  Desaguadero

Su mayor sueños construir su casita para poder vivir mejor, ya que ahora esta viviendo en la casa D. sus papas, también le gustaría poner una tienda para su vejez.

A ella le gustan los ahorros,  sus utilidades y las reuniones cuando comparten con sus compañeras del Banco Comunal
texts.en:
Daniela belongs to the "Virgen del Rosario" Community Bank, in Queñuani Community, Yunguyo district, Chuchito province, Puno department. She is 52 years old and the mother of 6 children (three of them are already married). Daniela is married, has an elementary school education, and lives in the Progreso neighborhood of Queñuani. She has been working with the Manuela Ramos Movement since the Community Bank was started. With an initial loan of 300 PEN Daniela was able to start her business buying and selling aji chiles. She now needs to borrow 3000 PEN to invest in her current business, buying aji and then reselling it in markets in Desaguadero. Her biggest dream is to build a little house to improve her life, since she currently lives in her parents' house. She would also like to start a store for when she is older. She likes to save and earn, and the meetings where she gets together with the other members of the Community Bank.

Translated from Spanish by Anne Kamsvaag, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of aji chiles

loans.name: Carmen

texts.en:
Carmen T. is from the village of Navalan. She is fifty-four years old and married with five grown children. To make a living, Carmen owns and operates a business raising ducks for sale. Carmen has been engaged in her business for over eighteen years and earns approximately $110 a month for these activities.

In 2008, Carmen joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to engage in business activities. Carmen is requesting a new loan of 14000 PHP, which will be used to purchase baby ducks to raise and sell in the future. This will be her fourth loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC: (Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative) PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy baby ducks to raise and sell

loans.name: Mina

texts.en:
Mrs. Mina S. is a grocery shopkeeper in the Town of Thecho. She opened her shop a year ago to improve the living standard of her family. She sells in her shop different types of grocery goods like rice, bitten rice, maize, and snacks.

Due to the poor economic condition of her family she cannot invest in her business so she is unable to fulfill the demands of her customers So Mrs. S. is requesting an Rs. 20,000 loan to buy different varieties of grocery items for her shop.

Mrs. S. lives with her husband, one son, a daughter-in-law and one grandson. Her husband, Mr. Sunil S., is employed in a private office.

Mrs. S. wishes to use her income to provide better education for her grandson and to help her husband with household expenses.

loans.use: To buys grocery items for her store

loans.name: Dilafruz

texts.ru: Клиентка Толибова Дилафруз занимается торговлей уже 5-лет.Возраст 36 лет. Замужем, имеет 1 ребенка. Проживает в городе Душанбе. Клиентка имеет собственную торговую точку, которая находится в городе Душанбе на рынке "Шохмансур". Клиентка  торгует  женской и мужской одеждой. Толибова Дилафруз закупает товар на рынке "Корвон". Она просит 1000 долларов сроком на 10 месяцев,  для пополнения товараоборота.
texts.en:
Dilafruz T. has been in the retail business for five years now. She is 36 years old. She is married and has one child. She lives in the city of Dushanbe. The client has own vendor spot which is located in Dushanbe on the Shohmansur market. She sells women's and men's clothing. Dilafruz buys the merchandise on the market Korvon. She is asking for a loan in the amount of 1000 dollars for a term of 10 months to increase circulation of goods.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase circulation of goods

loans.name: Edith

texts.es:
Edith es socia del Banco Comunal Ccatarisun que significa Levantémonos en quechua.
Edith es soltera, tiene 23 años, Edith vende paltas, productos que adquiere en la la ciudad de Pampas y lo vende en el mercado de frutas de la ciudad de Lima, de donde adquiere frutas variadas como durazno.
Edith necesita un préstamo de 2000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de paltas.
Los sueños de Edith son tener una tienda de venta de computadoras.
texts.en:
Edith is a member of the cooperative bank Ccatarisun, which means "Let's rise up" in Quechua. Edith is single and 23 years old. She acquires avocados in the city of Pampas and sells them in the fruit market in the city of Lima. In the Lima market, she acquires various fruits such as peaches. She needs a loan of $700, which will be invested in avocados. The dream of Edith is to have a store that sells computers.

Translated from Spanish by Jeff Schell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of avocados

loans.name: Rebecca Akinyi

texts.en:
Rebecca is an industrious lady married to Edward, an electrician. They have three children. She sells stationery, photocopying, laminating and more. She has been in business for three years and it is located in the heart of Migori town, a strategic point for this type of business.

Rebecca learned about KADET Ltd through a friend at a time when she needed capital to expand her business. This is her first loan from KADET Ltd. She intends to use the money to purchase another computer to increase the speed at which she can typeset for clients. She has an employee assisting her.

She aspires to start a computer class, which will increase her income and help others improve their literacy skills.

------------- About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is committed to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services in order to relieve suffering and improve living conditions in communities across Kenya.

loans.use: Purchase an extra computer.

loans.name: Jonathan

texts.en:
Jonathan is a bread vendor. He is 25 years old and married to Mary Jane. They do not have a child yet but they are starting to save for their future children and to improving their standard of living. He purchases his products from a nearby bakeshop, then he uses his motorcycle to deliver bread inside and outside their village. His income from the business is really a big help in meeting daily needs at home.

Jonathan has applied for a loan of 4,000 PHP for additional business capital to purchase more bread that he can sell. He will also use some of the money for maintenance of his motorcycle for a safer ride. He is hoping that someday he can have his own bakeshop. He will do his best, work hard and learn to always be patient, he says.

loans.use: For additional business capital

loans.name: Estrilia

texts.en:
Estrilia A., 57 years old, is married to Rodelio and a resident of Siare Sindangan, Zamboanga del Norte. Her husband is a fisherman. The fish caught by her husband will be sold at the public market or to their neighbors. They have been in this business for many years already. 


Because they wanted to buy fishing nets, both agreed to join Paglaum MPC on January 30, 2008 to have access to a loan. But aside from financial assistance they received, they also enjoyed the add-on benefits like insurance, savings etc. Since she wants to be more productive, she is applying for a loan amounting to 10,000PHP. She believes that with Paglaum’s help, and with the patience & diligence of her husband, she is looking forward to being a successful vendor someday and can own a stall at the public market.

loans.use: Additonal Capital for business

loans.name: Breny

texts.es:
Breny, de 35 años, es una madre de familia muy alegre y amorosa, vive en una casa alquilada, ya que tuvo problemas con su propia casa, la cual tuvo que dejar. Tiene 2 hijos menores y lo que más desea es darles una buena educación. La venta de zapatos es la actividad principal que realiza Breny, pero actualmente su puesto de zapatos no le esta brindando los ingresos que necesita, es por eso que adicionalmente decidió vender, en el mismo lugar, repuestos para celulares y pequeños aparatos musicales, los cuales le ayudan a obtener un mejor ingreso económico para su familia.

Ella siempre amará su negocio de zapatos, pero su nuevo trabajo es una actividad que también le llama mucho la atención, lleva 18 años en la venta de zapatos y 6 meses vendiendo repuestos, siente que lo más difícil es tener que permanecer todo el día en su puesto de venta sin poder salir a la calle a realizar sus actividades. 

Para un futuro cercano, espera hacer crecer su negocio y poner una tienda más grande donde pueda vender sus zapatos y sus repuestos con mayor comodidad.

Este es el segundo préstamo de Breny con MFP, sabe que tiene que pagarlo a tiempo y está dispuesta a hacerlo, puesto que quiere acceder a otros préstamos en el futuro, en su banco comunal es muy alegre. Con los mil quinientos soles solicitados comprará más zapatos y repuestos de celulares para implementar mejor su puesto de venta y no descuidar sus dos negocios.
texts.en:
Breny, 35 years old, is a happy and loving mother. She lives in a rented house, as she had problems in the house she owned and had to leave. She has two small children, and her greatest desire is to provide them with good educations. Breny’s primary activity is selling shoes, but her footwear stall is not currently generating the income she needs. For this reason, she decided to also sell cell phone parts and small music electronics from the same location to generate additional income for her family. She will always love her business selling shoes, but her new line of business is an activity that also brings her a lot of attention. She’s been selling shoes for 18 years, and electronics for 6 months. The hardest part about her work is staying in her stall all day, without being able to leave to run errands. In the near future, she hopes to make her business grow and open a larger store where she can sell her products in more comfort. This is Breny’s second loan with MFP, and she knows she must make her payments on time. She is committed to do so, since she would like to have access to credit again in the future. She is very happy in her cooperative bank. She plans to use the one thousand five hundred Peruvian soles she is requesting to buy more shoes and electronics to supply her stall, and to not neglect her business.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase additional merchandise.

loans.name: Jessica Esmeralda

texts.es:
La señora JESSICA ESMERALDA V. P. tiene 32 años, vive en el distrito de Salaverry, provincia de Trujillo, departamento La Libertad – Perú. La socia pertenece al Banco Comunal LAS EMPRESARIAS AL ÉXITO II. Ella presenta estudios técnicos de cosmetología,  es conviviente y tiene 2 hijos en edad escolar quienes dependen económicamente de ella. La socia se dedica a la venta de cosméticos y también realiza cortes e cabello, pintados, peinados, etc. a sus vecinos, amistades y familiares. Con su primer crédito de 300 nuevos soles compró 2 tijeras, 1 secadora y tintes.
Con este crédito de 1,500 nuevos soles tiene planificado viajar a Lima y comprar tintes de  cabello al por mayor para así poder aumentar sus ganancias. JESSICA sueña con tener su propio centro de belleza en su domicilio para así poder trabajar con mayor tranquilidad.
texts.en:
Mrs Jessica Esmeralda V. P. is 32 years old and lives in the Salaverry district, province of Trujillo, department La Libertad in Peru. The member belongs to the Community Bank "Las Empresarias al Exito II (The Businesswomen Toward Success). She has completed technical studies in cosmetology, lives with her partner and has 2 school age children who financially depend on her. The associate sells cosmetics and also cuts, colors, and styles hair for her neighbors, friends and family members. She used her first loan of 300 New Soles to purchase 2 pairs of scissors, a hair dryer and hair dyes. She is planning to use this loan of 1,500 New Soles to travel to Lima to buy hair color at wholesale and thus be able to increase her income. Jessica dreams of having her own beauty center in her home and therefore be able to work more peacefully.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Bobbit, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To travel to Lima to buy hair color at wholesale.

loans.name: Rejoice

texts.en: Rejoice is 32 years old and married with four children. She lives in Delta State, Nigeria. She sells bricks to help provide for the basic needs of her family. She requests a loan of NGN 80000 to purchase more cement and sand to mold more bricks to sell. Her business is booming and the loan will help her to expand it even more, increasing her earnings for the long run so she can better provide for the education of her children.

loans.use: To purchase more cement and sand for moldings bricks.

loans.name: Olajumoke

texts.en: Olajumoke, 40, is a widow with three children. Her eldest child is 11 years old and the youngest child is six years old. Olajumoke lives in Ibadan, Oyo State, Nigeria. She sells gift items at retail prices to her customers. She hopes to own a shop in the future. She is requesting a loan in the amount of 50,000 NGN to purchase more gift items to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more gift items to sell

loans.name: Ami Massan

texts.fr: Cette jeune femme s’est lancée pour sa toute première fois dans le commerce de pagnes, plus tard elle y a associé le commerce de mèches et de produits de beauté, ce qui a contribué a accroître son chiffre d’affaire. la période des fêtes de fin d’année a entrainé une hausse de la demande, elle voudrait en profiter pour maximiser son profit raison pour laquelle elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour acheter  12 pièces de pagnes de qualité HI-Target, 10  cartons de mèches et divers produits de beauté. Etant célibataire, c’est cette activité qui lui permet de bien subvenir à ses propres besoins.
texts.en:
This young woman initially got started in the commerce of pagnes (colorful West African cloth). Later on, she included commerce in hair extensions and beauty products. This has helped to increase her sales. The year-end holiday period has lead to a jump in demand. She would like to take advantage of it to maximize her profits. For these reasons, she's requesting a WAGES loan to buy 12 bolts of quality HI-Target pagnes, 10 boxes of hair extensions, and a variety of beauty products. Her business really enables her to support herself, being unmarried.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying cloth, hair extensions, and beauty products

loans.name: Las Cenzontles Group

texts.es:
El grupo Cenzontle está integrado por tres mujeres ellas son Paula R., María Félix H. y María G..  El lema de estas formidables féminas es seguir adelante y progresar.

R. se dedica a la venta de cosméticos de manera ambulante enfrentando el arduo sol de la mañana y los peligros que asechan a la ciudad. De la misma manera trabaja María G. quien comercializa cosméticos por catalogo.

Mientras H. trabaja realizando y vendiendo cajetas, cosa de horno y pozol en su casa de habitación.
texts.en:
The Cenzontle is made up of three women: Paula R., María Félix H., and María G.. The motto of this formidable females is to keep moving forward and progressing. R. works selling makeup door-to-door in the arduous sun and the dangers that exist in the city. María G. does the similar work selling makeup through catalogues. Meanwhile, H. works making and selling candies, baked goods, and pozole (a traditional stew/soup).

Translated from Spanish by Patrick King, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cosmetics for resale

loans.name: Nelma

texts.en:
Nelma Y. is from the village of Sapang Dalaga, Misamis Occidental.  She is 55 years old, married and has 2 adult-age children. To make a living, Nelma owns & operates a tailoring business.  The main source of income for the business comes primarily from sewing and the rental of gowns to the local community. Nelma has been engaged in her business for 11 years and earns approximately 9,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Nelma joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nelma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to provide additional capital for the needs of her tailoring business. Nelma is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory. This loan will be the 5th loan taken out by Nelma from PMPC and the 2nd one to be funded by Kiva. Nelma plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To provide additional capital and to purchase additional inventory

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce I. is currently in the business of selling local alcoholic beverages and charcoal and is requesting a loan to buy more ingredients to use to make alcohol to sell.  Joyce is 20 years old and is married to a husband who is a driver. She has one child and her child does not go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a bar.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: buy more materials to use and make alcohol to sell.

loans.name: Oumou Mamadou

texts.fr:
Madame Oumou Mamadou T. est âgée de 29 ans, mariée  et mère  de 3 enfants.  Elle  vit chez son mari  dans une grande famille traditionnelle au quartier Pelengana village de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
N’ayant fréquenté  l’école pour des raisons sociales, elle commença très tôt à faire des activités génératrices de revenus auprès de sa mère qui faisait le commerce d’articles divers. Nantie des années expériences passées à côté de cette dernière, elle évolue seule depuis maintenant 10 ans. Oumou  opta pour le commerce de condiments alimentaires.  Elle jouit d’une grande clientèle due à la qualité des condiments qui sont de première qualité et bien conservés.   
Dans le dessein d’augmenter son fonds de commerce, afin de réaliser plus de bénéfices, elle a fait recours à Soro Yiriwaso. Elle est en relation avec cette dernière depuis 48 mois. Après 3 prêts solidaires et 3 prêts individuels  tous correctement bien remboursés, elle est à son 4ème prêt individuel qu’elle compte utiliser pour acheter, 4 sacs de poudre de feuilles de baobab. Elle s’approvisionne dans les villages environnants de Ségou tels que Konodimini, Gassela etc.
Madame Oumou Mamadou T. vend au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Avec ce prêt, elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 75 000FCFA. Ce bénéfice lui permet de payer les cotisations de tontines et de rembourser les intérêts du prêt de Soro Yiriwaso. 
Son ambition est de construire une maison à usage d’habitation.
texts.en:
Ms. Oumou Mamadou T. is 29 years old, married, and the mother of three children.  She lives with her husband in a large traditional family in the Pelengana district, Ségou City (4th  administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Not having attended school for societal reasons, she very soon started to earn in income along with her mother, who used to do commerce in various goods.  Privileged with years of previous experience at her mother's side, Oumou has been advancing on her own for ten years now.  She opted for commerce in condiments.  She enjoys a large customer base due to the quality of her condiments, which are top grade and well-kept.  With plans to increase her business capital in order to make more profits, she turned toward micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso.  She has had an association with it for 48 months.  After three solidarity loans and three individual loans, all properly repaid, she is now on her fourth individual loan, which she intends to use for buying four sacks of powdered baobab leaves.  She gets her supplies from the villages surrounding Ségou, such as Konodimini, Gassela etc.  She accepts cash or credit from customers composed of women and men.  With this loan, Oumou envisions making a monthly profit of 75,000 francs CFA.  This profit will enables her to pay her tontine dues and to repay the Soro Yiriwaso loan.  Her ambition is to build a house in which to live.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying powdered baobab leave

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: purchase of maize

loans.name: Saketh's Group

texts.en: This group loan has four people who are villagers in Preaek Bak village in Kandal province. Mrs. SaKeth T. is the group leader. She has been selected by all the members. They will use the loan for different purpose. She is a housewife who cooks delicious food for her family. Her husband, Mr. Thon Mouv, is a fisherman who can find some fish to sell to support his family. They have a problem because they do not have enough supplies for fishing. Thus, in order to improve their living conditions, Mrs. SaKeth T. decided to ask for a loan to buy a boat for fishing. This couple has eight children. One child is a laborer, one is a fish seller, four are enrolled in a local public school, and the others are too young to go to school or work.

loans.use: To buy a boat for fishing

loans.name: Elizabeth's Group

texts.en:
Elizabeth P. is from the town of Wigan Cordon. She is 32 years old and the leader of a six-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Elizabeth P.'s group.

Elizabeth is married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, she runs a general store selling a variety of different products. She has been engaged in this business for over five years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month.

In 2006, Elizabeth joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She successfully repaid a previous loan of 19000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Elizabeth is requesting a new loan of 19000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the ninth loan taken out by Elizabeth from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Miguel

texts.es:
El señor Miguel vive en casa propia con su esposa e hijos en la zona de alto Chijini; de profesión músico, la actividad que el realiza es la de tocar en una orquesta los fines de semana en acontecimientos sociales, donde percibe una ganancia que le permite mantener a su familia.

El crédito que solicita es para comprar instrumentos musicales para seguir en su actividad..

Es la primera vez que silicita crédito en  Impro y el análisis de su flujo de ingresos y egresos muestra que  puede acceder a un crédito.
texts.en:
Miguel lives with his wife and children in his own home located in the Alto Chijini zone. He is a professional musician who plays in a band at social gatherings on the weekends. This allows him to earn enough of an income to be able to support his family. He is asking for this loan in order to buy musical instruments to be able to continue his trade. This is his first loan through Impro. The analysis of his income and expenses qualifies him for this loan.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Musical instruments

loans.name: Mana Group

texts.es:
El grupo el Mana está integrado por cuatro mujeres trabajadoras y esforzadas una de ella es  Karla Janett B. coordinadora del grupo quien  inicio con la venta de refresco y luego con las ganancias y los prestamos invirtió en productos para formar su modesta venta.

Sus compañeras de grupo son Susana María A. se dedica a realizar tortilla y vende frijoles cosidos y crudos hace un año y cuatro meses,  Nelly del Socorro tiene una pulpería y Estela Antonia Z. S. empezo comercializando jocotes y pinolillo en la actualidad vende ropa y calzado.Ellas invertiran los creditos en sus negocios 
para que este cresca.
texts.en:
The group "Mana" is made up of 4 hardworking women. One of them is Karla Janett B., who is the coordinator of the group. She started out selling soft drinks, and later with the earnings and some loans she invested in products to set up her small store. Her fellow group members are Susana María A., who has made tortillas and sold cooked and raw beans for a year and 4 months. Nelly del Socorro has a grocery store and Estela Antonia Z. S. started out selling plums and pinolillo (a drink made of cocoa and toasted corn), and currently sells clothing and shoes. They will invest the loans in their businesses to make them grow.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy staple grains, meat, etc.

loans.name: Quirwin

texts.en: Quirwin E. is from the village of Acad, Aurora, Zamboanga Del Sur. He is 38 years old. Quirwin is married and has seven school-aged children. To make a living, Quirwin raises crops. The main source of income for his business comes from planting and harvesting corn for sale. Quirwin has been engaged in his business for more than two years and earns approximately 8,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2009, Quirwin joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Quirwin has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from GDMPC, a Kiva partner. This previous loan was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. Quirwin is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the third loan taken out by Quirwin from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small-scale entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To finish building his house

loans.name: Jiguiseme V Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe JIGUISEME V  sont des femmes mariées du village de Kampogosso Kafonon dans de SAN, région de Ségou, qui  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles élargies, ayant  en moyenne 32 ans,  5 enfants et cultivent  de l’arachide. 
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant 3 ans. Après avoir correctement remboursé  les  prêts précédents, elles sont à leur troisième prêt de campagne.
MAMOU YACOUBA D. compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semence d’arachide, des petits matériels et des intrants,  au grand marché de Kimparana. Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de Kimparana. Les ventes se fond aussi dans les  marchés  environnants en détail (souvent en gros) au comptant à une clientèle composée de consommateurs et de revendeurs venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 30 000 à 55 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé  pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
The members of the group JIGUISEME V are married women from the village of Kampogosso Kafonon in the prefecture of San, in the region of Ségou, who live in extended traditional families. They are, on average, 32 years old and have five children. They cultivate peanuts. In hopes of increasing the profits from their agricultural work, the members of the group decided three years ago to participate in the loan program through Soro Yiriwaso. After having properly repaid their previous loans, they are now on their third business loan. Mamou Yacouba D. plans to use her loan to buy an adequate quantity of peanut seeds, small tools, and fertilizer at the main market of Kimparana. After the winter season, the crops are stored for a length of time so that their value will increase before being sold at the main market of Kimparana. They also make their sales in neighboring markets at retail (and often at wholesale), in cash, to customers who generally come from large cities. The members of the group each plan to earn, after the sale of their agricultural products, a profit of 30,000 to 55,000 FCFA which will be used to pay the interest on the loan and to meet daily family expenses.

Translated from French by Shannon Arnold, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of fertilizer, seeds, and small equipment

loans.name: Luis Manuel

texts.es: Luis Manuel  tiene una pulpería de venta tanto de alimentos y productos de uso diario en su comunidad. Tiene dos hijos menores de edad a su cargo, por lo que cada día lucha por proporcionarle los servicios básicos. Su negocio está ubicado en su casa de habitación, pues cuando inicio fue con cafetín en donde ofrecía café, jugos, pan, repostería, galletas y golosinas pero con el paso del tiempo logro obtener un buen capital y establecer su negocio en su vivienda. Este es su primer financiamiento destinado para la compra de golosinas, refrescos, pan, galletas y granos básicos.
texts.en:
Luis Manuel has a grocery store where he sells food items and daily use items in his community. He has two minor children under his care which motivate him to work daily to provide them with the basics. His store is located in his home because when he started out he had a small snack bar where he sold coffee, juices, bread, pastry, cookies and sweets. In time he acquired enough capital to set up his store in his home. This is his first loan and it will be used to buy sweets, beverages, bread, cookies and basic grains.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy stock items for his store.

loans.name: Ana Victoria

texts.es: Ana Victoria B. de 23 años de edad, vive junto a su madre, junto a su hermano y un hijo de 1 año de edad, junto a los cuales reside en El Transito, ubicado en el departamento de San Miguel. Ella posee una tortillería y comedor en el cual se encarga de elaborar deliciosos almuerzos, esto lo realiza con la ayuda de su madre quien le ayuda en el negocio, durante 5 años ella  ha trabajado arduamente por el bienestar de su familia y ahora por el de su hijo, ya que Ana es madre soltera, razón por la cual debe esforzarse el doble por poder brindarles todo lo necesario  a su pequeño, el cual se ha convertido en la razón principal de todo para ella. Ana solicita un préstamo a través del cual pueda compra maíz para la elaboración de las tortillas, esto debido a que cuenta con muy buena clientela, y ella desea poder atender a más clientes, puesto que en muchas ocasiones por falta de masa no ha podido atender a mas personas, es por ello que solicita el préstamo el cual le permita comprar más materia prima tanto para elaborar las tortillas como también para comprar todo lo necesario para realizar mayor cantidad de almuerzos y así vender más y obtener mayores ganancias.
texts.en:
Ana Victoria B. is 23 years old and lives with her mother, brother and her 1 year-old son in El Transito, located in San Miguel. She owns a tortilla shop and eatery, where she works at preparing delicious lunches. She does this with the aid of her mother who has been helping her for 5 years now. She’s worked hard for the well being of her family and now for the well being of her son. Since Ana is a single mother she must work doubly hard to provide everything for her little one who has become her all. Ana is asking for a loan to purchase corn for her tortillas so she can increase her customer base, which is already very good. She will use the loan to purchase ingredients for both her tortillas as well as for her lunches so she may sell more and earn more profits.

Translated from Spanish by Maya Wisnievitz, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of corn and ingredients for food

loans.name: Leonora

texts.en:
Leonora S. is from the village of Kimanait, Pangantucan, Bukidnon. She is 44 years old. Leonora is married and has 4 adult children. To make a living, Leonora owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Leonora has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Leonora joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Leonora has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Leonora is requesting a new loan of 18000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This will be the 6th loan taken out by Leonora from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory & working capital.

loans.name: Flores Magon Group

texts.es:
Esta unidad de desarrollo se llama “FLORES MAGON” comentan que le pusieron ese nombre al grupo por que la mayoría de las integrantes viven en ese andador llamado Flores Magon. Este grupo está ubicado en el municipio de Zitacuaro en el estado de Michoacán. El grupo está conformado por 11 integrantes. 
La representante del grupo se llama María Socorro S. Díaz. Doña Soco como le dice su familia y conocidos tiene 43 años de edad, estudio la carrera técnica de secretaria ejecutiva, dice que no ejerció su carrera por que se caso muy joven y su esposo ya no la dejo trabajar para que se dedicara por completo a su casa e hijos. Doña Soco, es una mujer muy trabajadora, su esposo con el tiempo se dio cuenta que no era suficiente lo que el ganaba para mantener a su familia por eso ella decidió ayudarlo con los gastos del hogar, y entonces emprendió un negocio de plásticos. Ahora ellos dos se dedican a la venta de bolsa de plástico, vasos, platos de unicel, cucharas, tenedores, etc. Comenta que sus clientes son gente que tiene puestos en el mercado, tortilleros y panaderos, tiene trabajando en este hace 7 años, tiene su puesto de plásticos fuera del mercado de Zitacuaro Michoacán donde también vende ropa interior para dama y manualidades como juegos de baño, servilletas, bolsas decoradas etc. La señora Socorro está casada con el señor Mario desde hace 22 años ellos tienen 3 hijas de nombres Marisol de 22 años, Stephanie de 19 años de edad, ellas dos casadas, y Carol de 17 años quien estudia la licenciatura en pedagogía en la escuela normal de Zitacuaro, doña Socorro tiene la esperanza que su hija la menor termine la carrera porque dice que es la mejor herencia que un padre le puede dejar a sus hijos.
  
Roció Sanromán M., ella es parte del grupo “Flores Magon”, tiene 29 años, está estudiando la preparatoria abierta en este momento porque sus papas no tenían dinero para comprarle el uniforme y los utiles escolares, dice que su esposo es una gran ayuda para ella porque él la motiva a salir adelante para que estudie una carrera. Doña Rosi como le dicen sus amigos y familiares se dedica a vender dulces, jugos, chicharrones preparados con soya, refrescos, frituras, paletas de hielo etc., frente al hospital regional de Zitacuaro, tiene con su negocio 2 años, comenta que empezó a vender sus jugos y demás cosas porque ella veía que las personas que tenían enfermos en el hospital no tenían que almorzar y por eso ella decidió poner su puesto, otro de los motivos por el cual puso su puesto fue que le quería ayudar a su esposo con los gastos de la casa. La señora Rosi, está casada con el señor Salvador, el es abogado y tienen una niña de seis años llamada Leylan que estudia el primer año de primaria. Dice la señora Rosi que su meta en la vida es poder hacer un local estable donde pueda vender sus dulces y vender bisutería ya que le gusta diseñar collares y pulseras de pedrería, otra de sus metas es terminar la preparatoria y terminar la carrera de Licenciado en Derecho. Comenta que con las ganancias que saque de vender sus dulces y jugos ahorrara para comprar un terreno para hacer el local que tanto sueña.

Los otros 9 integrantes se llaman María Guadalupe Julián C., Reyna P. E., Isabel M. García, Clementina Solís S., Stephanie Sanromán S., Teresa López P., Perla Janeth M. López Azucena Julián C., María Amparo S. N., ellas quieren los préstamos para invertir en venta de colchas por catalogo, venta de dulces, zapatos por catalogo, manualidades, panadería, cosméticos por catalogo etc.
texts.en:
This development unit is called “FLORES MAGON” [Cipriano Ricardo Flores Magón (September 16, 1874 — November 21, 1922) was a noted Mexican anarchist and social reform activist]. They tell us that they named it thus because most of the members live in a place called Flores Magón. The group is located in the town of Zitácuaro in the state of Michoacán. It has 11 members. The group representative is María Socorro S. Díaz. Doña Soco, as her family and acquaintances call her, is 43 years old. She studied to be an Executive Secretary but says that she never practiced her profession because she married very young and her husband didn’t let her work so that she could dedicate herself totally to home and children. Doña Soco is a very hard working woman. Her husband realized in time that what he earned wasn’t sufficient to support the family so she decided to help him with household expenses and started her plastics business. Now, both of them sell plastic bags, drinking glasses, Styrofoam dishes, spoons, forks, etc. She tells us that her customers are people who have stands in the market, tortilla makers and bakers. She has been in this business for 7 years and has her plastics stand outside the Zitácuaro, Michoacán market where she also sells women’s underwear and crafts like bathroom sets, napkins, decorated purses, etc. Socorro has been married to Mario for 22 years and they have three daughters: Marisol, 22, Stephanie, 19, both married, and Carol, 17 who is studying to be a teacher at the Zitácuaro Normal School. Socorro hopes that her youngest daughter finishes her career because she says that’s the best inheritance a parent can leave her children. Roció Sanromán M., 29, is also part of the “Flores Magón” group. She is currently finishing high school in the Open High School program because her parents couldn’t afford to buy her uniforms and school supplies back when she was in regular school. She says her husband is a great help to her because he encourages her to continue forward and study a career. Doña Rosi, as her friends and family refer to her, sells candies, juices, chicharrones (made from soy), soft-drinks, snacks, popsicles, etc. in front of the Zitácuaro Regional Hospital. She has had the business for two years. She comments that she started selling juices and other items because she noticed that family members of patients in the hospital didn’t have anything to eat at lunch so she decided to set up her stand. Another motive behind her doing this is that she wanted to help her husband meet household expenses. Rosi is married to Salvador, who is an attorney, and they have a six year old daughter named Leylan who is in first grade. Rosi says that her life goal is to have a stable location where she can sell her candy and also sell costume jewelry because she likes to design jeweled necklaces and bracelets. Another one of her goals is to finish high school and then complete a career in Law. She says that profits from the candy and juice sales will be to buy the lot to build the locale she so dreams of. The other nine group members are: María Guadalupe Julián C., Reyna P. E., Isabel M. García, Clementina Solís S., Stephanie Sanromán S., Teresa López P., Perla Janeth M. López Azucena Julián C. and María Amparo S. N.. They want the loans to invest in several lines of work: catalogue bedspread sales, candy sales, catalogue shoe sales, arts and crafts, bakery, catalogue cosmetics sales, etc.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy plastic items: bags, dishes, spoons, etc.

loans.name: Emilio

texts.es: Emilio tiene la edad de 22 años, es soltero, y vive con sus padres. El quiere comprar dos vacas terneros para engordar y en varios años venderlos en el mercado. Sus padres y el ha dedicado varios años a su finca y quieren aumentar el número de animales de diferentes edades y aumentar su hato. Cuenta con varios animales ya, un área de potrero de buena calidad, y una zona adecuada para esta actividad. Está el primer préstamo que ha recibido de FUDECOSUR y está muy contento con las facilidades que se le brindaron. El espera de tener más ingresos para invertir en la finca y con las ganacias brindarle a su familia una mayor estabilidad económica.
texts.en:
Emilio, 22, is single and lives with his parents.  He wants to buy two calves to fatten up and take them to market to sell in a few years.  His parents and he have dedicated several years to their farm and they want to increase the number of animals of different ages and increase herd size.

He has several animals already, a pasture area in good condition, and an area that is adequate for this type of activity.

This is his first loan from FUDECOSUR and he is very happy with the terms offered.  He hopes to have more income to invest in the farm and use the profits to provide his family with greater economic stability.

loans.use: To buy calves to raise.

loans.name: Innocent

texts.en: Innocent is 27 years old. He is single. He has adopted 3 children. Innocent sells beer and soft drinks, and he has had this business for 6 years. With this loan he will buy more beer and soft drinks to sell. With the profit he will buy food for his family. His business is unique because he is the only person who sells beer and soft drinks. In the future, he would like to become the sole distributor in the whole sector.

loans.use: To buy more beer and soft drinks to sell.

loans.name: Maria Benigna

texts.es:
Maria Benigna tiene 65 años y vive en la hermosa ciudad del Cusco, Perú, ella desde hace mucho tiempo que participa en el banco comunal “Patrón de San Sebastián” de la Unidad de Micro finanzas Arariwa. Maria Benigna es viuda y tiene dos hijos, ella es cesante del servicio de salud  y actualmente se dedica a la elaboración y venta de manualidades como bandas, carteras y muchas cosas más. 

Maria Benigna con su próximo préstamo que espera recibir de $ 50 USD, ella invertirá el dinero para aumentar el capital del negocio y desea comprar materiales como cuero, tela, botones, etc.   

La socia se encuentra agradecida por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
Maria Benigna is 65 years old and lives in the beautiful city of Cusco, Perú. For a long time, she has participated in the “Patrón de San Sebastián” communal bank of Asociación Arariwa. Maria Benigna is a widow and has two children. She is retired from the Health Service and now works and making and selling handicrafts, such as hair bands, wallets, and many others.

With this loan of $50USD, Maria Benigna will invest in raw materials, such as leather, cloth, buttons, etc. She is grateful for the opportunity provided by this loan. She commits to making her payments according to the schedule.

loans.use: Buy material for handicrafts, such as leather, cloth, and buttons.

loans.name: Riziki

texts.en:
Riziki is a married woman with two children, one attends school while the other one is still too young for school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are electricity bills and food for the family. 

For over five years, she has operated a Kikoi selling business, selling from home to her neighbours and passers-by.  She hopes to expand and open a boutique in the future. 

With the Kshs 40,000, she wants to purchase a bale of Kikoi's for resale. She decided to join Yehu to get loans to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase a bale of Kikoi's for resale

loans.name: Pheng

texts.en:
Pheng S., 29, is married and has two children.  They live in Takeo Province, Cambodia.  Pheng is employed at the factory, earning an income of about $3 per day.  She has to spend $20 on food, $5 on electricity and water and $20 on other necessities every month.  

Pheng is requesting a loan of $1000 to purchase a motorbike for her family.  In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: buy a motorbike for the family use

loans.name: Salim

texts.en:
Salim is a married man with five children, all of whom attend school. He owns a house that has electricity and piped water. His greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

He has operated a water selling business from home for the past three years, neighbours and passersby are his potential customers. Salim faces a major challenge of seasonality. During hot summer season the supply of water is low and demand is high. He hopes to own a retail shop in the future.

With the Kshs 40,000 he wants to purchase a water tap. He decided to join Yehu to get financial assistance to improve his business.

loans.use: To purchase a  water tap.

loans.name: Pablo Enrique

texts.es:
Pablo es un pequeño comerciante, casado y con una familia a quien a poyar. Su negocio es una pulpería que inicio hace tres años en donde ha venido aumentando de inventario mediantes financiamientos que la institución ha dado durante siete ciclos.
Lo que aumento de inventario así como sus niveles de ventas al ofrecer más productos, teniendo precios accesibles ya que compra en un mercado a proveedores y mayorista adquiriendo buenos precios.
Con este nuevo crédito será destinado a comprara productos de consumo en granos básicos de arroz, frijoles, azúcar, caja de jabón, bidón de aceite, golosinas, huevos, productos lácteos entre otra variedad de productos.
texts.en:
Pablo is a small businessman.  He is married and has a family to support.   His business is a small grocery store that he set up three years ago.  He has been increasing his inventory through loans from our institution over the course of seven loan cycles.  He has not only increased his inventory but also his sales levels as he now offers more products for sale.  He sells his products at affordable prices since he makes his purchases in the wholesale market and acquires his products for good prices.

Pablo will use this new loan to buy products such as basic grains, rice, sugar, boxes of soap, cans of oil, candies, eggs, dairy products ,etc.

loans.use: To buy basic grains, rice, beans, sugar, cans of oil, candies and other products

loans.name: Leonia

texts.en: Leonia is a 49-year-old single mother of three children. She lives in her own permanent house in Fort Portal, Uganda. Her dream for her family is to educate her children to the university level. For the past 20 years, she has been selling clothes. She continues to reap tangible benefits from her business, even with the challenge of limited capital. Leonia needs the loan to buy clothes to sell.

loans.use: To buy clothes to sell

loans.name: Paulina

texts.en:
A loving mother, 42-year-old Paulina is so worried about the lives of her five children who still live with her and are dependent on her. Instead of letting herself to be trapped in the middle of insecurities, in 2005, she joined a Kiva field partner in the Philippines -- ASHI -- to be able to access loans that will allow her productive self to flourish. 

Through previous loans she’s taken, she developed her fishing business. Profits she will be getting would augment her husband’s income as a fisherman, and as soon as her business grows, she will be able to support her children’s education until they finish college. By then, her role of being mother would be rewarded. 

Her relationship with ASHI and the loans she taken since she became a member helped her in running a business. Because of this, Paulina has solid records in repayment, attendance, and business (credit rating), thus making her qualified for a higher amount of loan. 

She is requesting a new loan to finance the maintenance of her fishing business. This loan will be utilized to purchase additional fish cages (fish traps) and fishing net to catch more fish to sell in her neighborhood and the nearby village.

Her long-term goals are to expand her fishing business into a fish-farm venture, to give her children brighter hopes, and to provide for other needs in order to enjoy the gifts of a life that’s full of blessing from almighty God and support from the good hearts of our Kiva supporters.

loans.use: To purchase additional fish cages (fish traps) and fishing net to catch more fish to sell

loans.name: Francisca

texts.es:
Francisca es socia del  Banco Comunal “Túpac Amaru”, ubicado en el distrito D. Yunguyo, provincia D. Yunguyo, departamento D. Puno, tiene 42 años D. edad.  Está casada y tiene 7 hijos.  Francisca no tiene estudios.
Su negocio consistente en la compra y venta D. animales menores como ganado porcino y ovino, también se dedica a la venta D. chuño en forma temporal. Trabaja con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos desD. hace doce años,  su préstamo inicial fue D. S/ 300.00 nuevo soles,  con lo que compró chanchos para engordarlos y luego venderlos.  Nos cuenta que su esposo trabaja en las construcciones como operario.
Con éste préstamo D. S/ 1000.00 nuevo soles, comprará un toro y trabajará con el engorD. D. ganado vacuno.
Su sueño es mejorar en su negocio y sobre todo mejorar sus ganancias. Lo que le gusta del Banco Comunal son las capacitaciones realizadas por la promotora D. crédito.
texts.en:
Francisca is a member of the “Túpac Amaru” community bank which is located in Yunguyo district, in Yunguyo province, in Puno department.  She is 42 years old, married, and has 7 children.  Francisca did not attend school.

Francisca's business is buying and selling small animals such as pigs and sheep.  She also sells 'chuño' (a freeze-dried potato product) seasonally.  Francisca has been working with Movimiento Manuela Ramos for twelve years.  Her first loan was for 300 Peruvian soles and she used that money to buy pigs to fatten and sell.  She tells us that her husband works as a construction worker.

Francisca will use this loan for 1,000 Peruvian soles to buy a bull and she will work fattening her cattle.

Francisca's dream is to improve her business and, above all, to improve her profits.  What she likes about her community bank are the training sessions that her loan officer provides.

loans.use: To buy a bull and to work fattening her cattle

loans.name: Dunchinsuren

texts.en:
Dunchinsuren, 49, is married and lives with his wife and three children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. They live in a ger, the Mongolian nomadic housing tent, on a small plot of land that they own on the outskirts of the city. They have a decent standard of living due to the transportation service business he started in 2000. He transports people from one side of the city to the other. Now his business has become more stable and his daily net income is around $64. 

He is an open-minded and hardworking person who says, "I am trying to make more money and build a house where we can have a comfortable life." He is requesting a loan of 1,800,000 MNT to buy spare parts and pay maintenance fees for his microbus.

loans.use: To buy spare parts

loans.name: Mary Trailyn

texts.en:
Mary Trailyn J. is from the village of Port Area, Iligan City. She is 29 years old. Mary Trailyn is married and has one infant child. To make a living, Mary Trailyn owns & operates a service-based business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from providing  computer services to local community members. Mary Trailyn has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Mary Trailyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mary Trailyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 13,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase tools needed to provide service. Mary Trailyn is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase tools needed for the maintenance of the service. This will be the 5th loan taken out by Mary Trailyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase tools needed for the maintenance of her computer service.

location.town: Port Area, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Jherome

texts.en:
Jherome L. is from the village of Bantuanon, Lantapan, Bukidnon. He is 22 years old and single.  Jherome owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. His main source of income comes from buying and selling canned goods, junk food, bread, biscuits, and candy in the local community. Jherome has been engaged in his business for over one year and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month.

In 2011, Jherome joined Hagdan sa Pag-uswag Foundation, Inc. (HSPFI) to access financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities.
